Whether thats a comment, or a flag, or and assignee, it wouldnt matter. Would just be nice to be able to communicate.

Cheers!

fields.description:
* The article saying how to do it [https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/deploy-build-artifacts-to-bitbucket-downloads-872124574.html|https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/deploy-build-artifacts-to-bitbucket-downloads-872124574.html]

h1. My pipeline output
!2595760462-pipeline.png|thumbnail!

h1. My downloads page
!604717197-my-downloads.png|thumbnail!

h1. The pipeline.yml
{code}
#!YAML

image: maven:3.3.3

pipelines:
    default:
        - step:
            script:
                - echo "Running DEFAULT"
                - mvn clean
                - mvn install
                - mvn javadoc:javadoc
                #- ant test
    branches:
        auto-deploy:
            - step:
                script:
                    ### Declare intentions.
                    - echo "Running on master."
                    ### Variables
                    - PROJ_NAME="phenomics-control-commons"

                    # Compile and test everything.
                    - mvn clean
                    - mvn install
                    

                    # Generate the javadocs.
                    - mvn javadoc:javadoc
                    
                    ### Okay, now we update the website.
                    - echo "Updating javadocs!"
                    - cd "$BITBUCKET_CLONE_DIR/.."
                    # Configure git
                    - git config --global user.email "automated-updater@noreply.com"
                    - git config --global user.name "$PROJ_NAME automated-updater"
                    # Clone the website repo.
                    - git clone "https://$WEB_AUTH@bitbucket.org/$BITBUCKET_REPO_OWNER/$BITBUCKET_REPO_OWNER.bitbucket.io.git"
                    - cd "$BITBUCKET_REPO_OWNER.bitbucket.io"
                    # Cleanout old version.
                    - rm -rf "$PROJ_NAME"
                    - rm -rf "projects/$PROJ_NAME"
                    - mkdir -p "projects/$PROJ_NAME"

                    # Add our files
                    - cp "$BITBUCKET_CLONE_DIR/webpage.html" "projects/$PROJ_NAME/index.html"
                    - cp "$BITBUCKET_CLONE_DIR/projectinfo.yml" "projects/$PROJ_NAME/projectinfo.yml"
                    - cp -r "$BITBUCKET_CLONE_DIR/target/site/apidocs" "projects/$PROJ_NAME/javadocs"

                    # append timestamp to project info
                    - "echo $'\\n' >> \"projects/$PROJ_NAME/projectinfo.yml\""
                    - "echo \"dateupdated: $(date +%s%3N)\" >> \"projects/$PROJ_NAME/projectinfo.yml\""

                    # Commit and push changes.
                    - git add -A
                    - git commit -m "Updated $PROJ_NAME javadocs."
                    - git push "https://$WEB_AUTH@bitbucket.org/$BITBUCKET_REPO_OWNER/$BITBUCKET_REPO_OWNER.bitbucket.io.git"

                    ### Finally, deploy to downloads.
                    - cd "$BITBUCKET_CLONE_DIR"
                    - mvn -B clean install
                    - curl -X POST --user "${BB_AUTH_STRING}" "https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories/${BITBUCKET_REPO_OWNER}/${BITBUCKET_REPO_SLUG}/downloads" --form files=@"target/phenomics-control-commons-1.0-SNAPSHOT.jar"
{code}

fields.description:
When a Pipelines is created through the REST API for a a branch, it requires a Bitbucket account to be present for the author of the revision involved.

However, the author of a revision does not necessarily have to match a Bitbucket account (this is matched based on email). Currently this causes failures during the creation of a Pipeline.

Workaround:

* users without a Bitbucket account can sign up for a Bitbucket account, using the same e-mail address that they using in their Git/Mercurial configuration
* users that have a Bitbucket account could also be affected if the email address of the Bitbucket account does not match the one used in the configuration of their local Git/Mercurial client. Information on how to address that can be found here: https://confluence.atlassian.com/display/BITBUCKET/Set+your+username+for+Bitbucket+Cloud+actions
fields.summary: Pipelines creation fails when the author does not have a Bitbucket account

To reproduce:

* Create a branch locally, commit some changes
* Push to remote (Bitbucket) and create a PR
* Rename your branch locally and remote following this guide: https://multiplestates.wordpress.com/2015/02/05/rename-a-local-and-remote-branch-in-git/
* Try to update your PR by clicking edit

The page at {{bitbucket.org/\{username\}/\{repository\}/pull-requests/update/\{pr\}}} will be broken. Showing JavaScript errors in the console, an endless loading spinner where the code is usually displayed and a broken branch selector on the source branch selector.

fields.description:
h3. Summary
If a user's full name in their Atlassian account contains characters from non-latin alphabets (e.g. 'ö'), their invitations to other users do not get sent.

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Edit your Full Name in your Atlassian account to include a character from a non-latin alphabet (e.g. ö)
# Go to a repo of yours in Bitbucket >> Settings >> User and group access
# In 'Users', type an email to invite (that has _no_ Bitbucket account yet)

h3. Expected Results
The email entered in step # 3 above gets an invitation

h3. Actual Results
No invitation is sent to that email.\\
In Chrome, if you open 'Developer Tools' >> 'Console', you will see a 500 error
fields.summary: If a user's full name in their Atlassian account contains characters from non-latin alphabets, then invitations do not get sent

fields.description:
We've had to disable the "Reset approvals when source branch is modified" merge check as it was generating a great deal of noise in some of our projects (because reasons, we've raised other issues ;)).

So, the suggestion I have is that the PR's author should be able to identify the need to reset approvals and request reviewers re-review, regardless of the settings applied.

So the flow would be:

# author raises PR
# reviewer approves
# author or another approver realises they need to make a substantial change
# substantial change is pushed to PR
# (here's the suggestion) author hits "Request re-review" kind of button
# approvals are reset and reviewers notified of the request

There are workarounds like declining the whole PR and raising a fresh one; but this would be a nicely nuanced option. I've noticed people are relatively uncomfortable declining PRs but they are quite happy to update and at-mention people requesting re-review.
fields.summary: Allow author to easily reset approvals on PRs

Instead of a "cannot find account" or similar error message, we simply close the transfer dialogue.
fields.summary: Creating warning for unknown / incorrect repository transfer

fields.description:
We start to work in a feature branch, say "foo". Make some changes in a commit, push that branch, make PR # 1 against the "master" branch to do the code review.

Once we approve the code review, we merge branch "foo" into the the "CI" branch, and our CI system builds that branch and runs tests.\\
Once that build finishes successfully, the CI branch creates PR # 2, and merges the "CI" branch into the "master" branch.\\
At that point, the commits from "foo" are in "master" and Bitbucket background task that updates all other PRs that are pointing at "master" goes through and finds the open PR # 1 they had used for code review and now marks it as "merged", but something in that logic is updating PR # 1 incorrectly, which is why the Commits tab doesn't list the commits, and the diff is coming out strange.
fields.summary: Incorrect information on pull request after merge

fields.description: These events take up to 10-15 minutes to be updated within JIRA.  This puts unnecessary delays within workflows to have to wait that long in between development, and updates.
fields.summary: PR merged / declined event is not picked up by DVCS immediately for the Cloud platform(FUSE-4175)

fields.description:
When a pull request is updated after an approval, then a "(see what's changed)" link appears.

This currently links to a diff between the commit of the approval and the latest commit of the pull request.

The pain I experience with this, is that if the new commit is a merge from master (e.g. an automerge from your CI tool), then the diff will show all the files that have changed on master, which the developer is not usually concerned about. It does not take into account the pull request destination, which already has these files.

Ideally, I would like this link to show how the files unique to the pull request have changed. I.e. limited to changes made directly on the branch, not including merge commits.

I have tried to workaround this by changing the destination of the diff to master, but this shows the whole pull request changes, not just the updates.

h2. Example
# Branch commit 1 - a.txt
# Merge back into branch from master - z.txt
# Branch commit 2 - b.txt

Expected for "see what's changed" between step 2 and step 1: "No changes"\\
Expected for "see what's changed" between step 3 and step 1 or step 2: "b.txt"
fields.summary: Improve "(see what's changed)" to show difference between

fields.description:
h3. Summary
Adding a user to a team user group with no 'Create repo' or 'Admin' permissions, does not send a notification to the user

h3. Steps to Reproduce
# Go to a Team of yours in Bitbucket >> {{Manage Team}}. The {{User groups}} page opens.
# See if you have a {{User group}} with *no* 'Create repo' or 'Admin' permissions. If not, create one.
# Select {{Add member}}.
# Add a user in the group form step # 2.

h3. Expected Results
The user receives a notification that they've been added to a user group.

h3. Actual Results
The user receives no notification.
fields.summary: Adding a user to a team user group with no 'Create repo' or 'Admin' permissions, does not send a notification to the user

fields.description: At times scrolling while scrolling during the logs being loaded, it jitters. Scrolling beyond the bottom line makes it jitters as well.
fields.summary: Scrolling in Pipelines jitters

fields.description:
The Bamboo build status is not shown on the PR if the merge strategy used is no-ff. The build status will go correctly against the merge commit however there is no link from the merge commit to the parent commits in the PR.

This behavior is different for other merge strategies:

Fast forward (from command-line): The commit shows up as part of the PR and hence so does the build status.

Squash (from UI): The squashed commit shows up in the PR with the build status.

Since the merge commit is not technically considered part of the PR, this behavior appears to be working as intended however some users would still like to see the build status displayed on the PR. Perhaps in the event of a merge commit, we can link the build status back to the parent commit or have a separate display of the build status for any resulting merge commits of a PR, on the PR.
fields.summary: When merge commit is used as the merge strategy, the Bamboo build status is not displayed on the PR

>>>from bitbucket.bitbucket importBitbucket

{{archive(self, repo_slug=None, format='zip', prefix=''):}}

Can Bitbucket-api specify the file to download?

fields.description:
We need to be able to require the approval of at last one member of a specific group.\\
eg.

Repository name: NewApp\\
Groups: Admin, Dev and Senior_Dev

When a pull-request is open from Dev_branch to Master, it's necessary that at last one Senior_Dev member to approve it.

fields.description:
I am not sure if this has been reported before (and possibly patched already), or if this is the proper channel to report it.

I realized that one can self-approve a PR (at least in v 4.10.1).

Reproduction steps.

# Person A creates a branch, opens a new PR and add Person B as a reviewer.
# Person B does another commit on that PR and pushes.
# The PR now has commits from Person A and Person B.
# Person B shouldn't be able to review it anymore. Yet, he is and he can self-approve and merge.

This bug has some security implications also.
fields.summary: Improper checking during PR reviews allows participants to +2 themselves.
Problem with Environment Variables while pulling an image from GCR

I know this is extreme and we had to create special test case, but it may happen in real life.

Expected: Default/target branch pipeline should be executed on the merged code.
fields.summary: Run pipeline on the result of the pull request merge commit

fields.description:
bq. the usage figures are seemingly unnecessarily buried. It feels like "usage" should show up anywhere that Pipelines settings are. even after following the directions:


bq. *Bitbucket Settings>Pipeline(Section)>Usage(Individual Account)/Team(Top Navigation Bar)>Click Team Name>Manage Team>Usage*


bq. I could not find my individual usage (maybe there's a bug on my account?) I FINALLY found the team usage (which is arguably the more important figure), but it was not at all intuitive. I've attached a screenshots outlining what I'm talking about.


--BBS-47819
fields.summary: Include Pipeline Usage figures in each repository's Pipelines page

fields.description:
Steps to repro:

# Go to a commit, click on the "+" icon and add a new tag.

A webhook is delivered with an empty {{push.changes}} array.

Now, create a tag and push from the command line with {{git tag foo; git push --tags}}. A webhook is delivered with {{push.changes[0].new.type: "tag"}} and the name of the tag as well.

I expect the webhook payload to include this data when I create a tag from the UI as well. Not getting this data makes it impossible for my CI system to trigger anything when users tag things from the BitBucket UI.
fields.summary: Creating tags from the UI sends two empty "push" "changes" in webhook payload

fields.description:
hi guys,

We're getting a warning in our bitbuckets about our primary repo being over 1gb

Cloning this locally appears to only show it being several hundred MB after garbage collection

Is there any way to kick off remote garbage collection or have this scheduled to run more frequently?
fields.summary: repo is (incorrectly?) reported as oversize, no mechanism to debug/fix this

fields.description:
Hi guys and @rahulchhabria,

We've got a smallish monolithic repo(~1.5Mloc) that we have been building with pipelines

So far pipelines itself is great and appears to have regular improvements, which we love - we're been tossing up moving away from internal buildbot and relying on this entirely

There are a couple of issues though that we are having trouble with, and have been wondering if there are nice solutions to:

* There appears to be no nice way to maintain build state, short of seeding the container with object files (eg checking in build artifacts). This means that even a tiny change results in a 40-60 minute build.

For this, we understand that letting people have incremental builds leads to a whole host of problems, but it'd be great to have an advanced feature that lets you maintain image state by default (acknowledging that you may get failed builds or weirdness) and only do a full build if specified, e.g. if there is an error

* Related, if people check in multiple commits we get multiple 40-60 minute builds (is there no build holfoff time as with buildbot? If it doesn't exist already it might be nice to have the option to only build head and not all intermediate commits)
* We can't build with any more than -j3 as we get a non-recoverable error halfway through the build that memory is exhausted. Peak build memory usage on our centos6 system with -j6 is 3.6GB (vs 2.6 with -j3 and 4.1 with -j8),  so I'm not sure why this doesn't work.

The fact that the error for OOM is fatal, non-recoverable, and takes 20 minutes to occur is itself counter-productive too - a continuable soft limit using cgroups or similar (perhaps including email warnings) would be infinitely preferable

* Having basic interactive console access to the system would be very helpful. Having to edit the pipelines yml, commit, wait for email error, repeat is a slow workflow

Apologies if any of these are covered in documentation - I haven't been through all of it in the last month or so, so will likely have missed things
fields.summary: Out of memory errors reported as failed pipelines, even when ignored

fields.description:
There are multiple pull requests and multiple commits for a file.\\
What would be good is have the ability to  aggregate comments from all commits and pull requests for a given file, so you can see them all comments in one place.\\
This provides a good way to look at past comments when you work on a file or with the code.\\
Otherwise, all the good thoughts are buried in some commit or pull request that were intended for collaboration.
fields.summary: Add the ability to view all comments across all commits and pull requests for a file in a Repo

fields.description:
Pretty common among CI solutions where if a branch success on tests, merge this branch to another branch.

There is no documentation on how to go about doing this
fields.summary: Auto-merge when pipeline passes

fields.description:
Problem:\\
When a file is renamed, the git history for that file is not linked to the previous file name.

When the following is executed:

* git checkout my_repo
* git mv ./my_repo/my_OLD_filename.rnd ./my_repo/my_NEW_filename.rnd
* git commit
* git push

The git history for "my_OLD_filename.rnd" is visible before commit X\\
The git history for "my_NEW_filename.rnd" is visible starting with commit X

Proposal:\\
Connect the git history for "my_OLD_filename.rnd " and "my_NEW_filename.rnd"
fields.summary: Connect commit history for a single file
Dashboard to see all projects status in Organisation Pipelines section

fields.description:
"Your account needs space for 6 users to complete this action, but you are currently on the 5 user plan."\\
!741886012-Screenshot%20from%202017-02-16%2012-27-59.png|thumbnail!

When I click to link "View" I see the next page:

!1742938151-Screenshot%20from%202017-02-16%2012-30-12.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: "View" link in upgrade plan tooltip is broken

fields.description:
When the "Reset approvals when source branch is modified" merge check is enabled, approvals are reset for _all_ updates to the branch including merge commits from master.

When the actual diff in the PR hasn't changed, it'd be nice to avoid the need for everyone to re-approve the PR.

Since merge commits are highlighted separately in commit activity streams we know the updates we want to ignore are already distinguishable in bitbucket's ui; so presumably it could be done :)

I can understand some projects may not want to ignore those commits, hence suggesting it as an option.

We have one project that auto-updates branches and the reset merge check had to be turned off again, which is a pity.
fields.summary: Add option to skip "Reset approvals when source branch is modified" if no changes are introduced

fields.description:
In Bitbucket Cloud, when trying to add payment details from _Bitbucket Settings > Plan details_ the _State_ field will in some cases return the error 'Invalid state' even if the name added is a valid state (see screenshot). This will prevent the user from completing the process and make the payment.

The issue is that state abbreviations are expected, but the error message does not make this clear.

*+Please note+* that you should be able to update your billing details if you enter the *_state abbreviation_*, instead of the full name of the state.

For example, for Indian state Haryana, instead of entering Haryana, you will need to enter the state abbreviation *HR* instead.
fields.summary: Improve 'Invalid state' error message when editing billing details

fields.description:
When writing a comment anywhere within Bitbucket, typing '@' will always treat the adjacent word as a username, even if you don't know that user and he doesn't have access to your repositories.

If the user has access to your repository, he'll be displayed in a dropdown while you're typing, this is expected. However, if none of your team mates matches that username you won't see any dropdown, but in the moment you save the comment, whatever you were writing using '@' will be replaced by the name of the Bitbucket username who matches, if any (the users won't receive any notification as they don't have access to the repositories).

It would be nice that the saved comment will just display what you see while you're editing, and that it doesn't mention any random users without previous notice.

As a workaround, it's possible to avoid it by writing the word into a code block with backticks, like for example {{@whatever}}. This will scape the @mention and show just what you write.
fields.summary: Using '@' in comments mentions random users

fields.description:
Some users often use the same emojis. Would be good to be able to add these to the tool bar so reviewing can use less typing.

A list of emojis can be found at https://bitbucket.org/DACOFFEY/wiki/wiki/BITBUCKET/EMOJI/Emoji?_ga=1.120413771.2118628899.1471273130
fields.summary: Allow favourite emojis to be added to tool bar

fields.description:
I generate de OAUTH like here is explained: https://confluence.atlassian.com/bitbucket/connect-bitbucket-cloud-to-jira-server-applications-814208991.html

I added the Keys correctly but I don't see any repositories and when click on Configurate automatic access I can see this warm in the log:

2017-02-15 13:12:21,671 http-bio-8081-exec-22 WARN juancarlos.cavero 792x2317650x1 16gui8y 83.61.8.69,10.0.0.95 /rest/bitbucket/1.0/organization/6/defaultgroups [bitbucket.clientlibrary.request.BaseRemoteRequestor] Failed to properly execute request [GET https://bitbucket.org/api/1.0/groups/billionlabs],\\
Params: org.apache.http.params.BasicHttpParams@261770d1,\\
Response code 403
fields.summary: Error linking bitbucket on cloud with jira server

fields.description: In the create issues, using the upload images function, clicking multiple times on upload creates multiple upload.
fields.summary: Using the Upload Images function in create issues, clicking multiple upload loads multiple times.

fields.description:
I Think that {{@brief}} and other doxygen style comments should not have to be put into backticks. In addition to this I think that if nothing is found after the {{@}} symbol has been types in then the string should be inserted verbatim.

Please see recording
fields.summary: Doxygen Comments not displaying correctly without backticks

fields.description:
When trying to run below API, it returns error when project field isn't mentioned.

https://api.bitbucket.org/1.0/repositories/{accountname}/{repo_slug} --data "description=long description"

For private repositories this works fine as they're not in a project.
fields.summary: Repository details update API 1.0 endpoint returns an error for repositories that belong to a team if project field is not sent within the request.

fields.description:
When adding more users to a bitbucket account and you have reached the limit, the page comes up to upgrade and offers to view users the access, but the VIEW link is bloken\\
see below an example:

http://prntscr.com/e84v3h

The VIEW link is taking users to :\\
https://bitbucket.org/account/user/gtesttest/plan-users/,\\
and we believe it should be going to https://bitbucket.org/account/user/gtesttest/plans-and-billing/
fields.summary: The view users with access link takes you to a wrong page

fields.description: When trying to debug why a bitbucket-pipelines.yml is not in correct format, it would be useful for BitBucket to display a breakdown of where the fault lies, especially when the file looks like it is correct, based on the documentation.
fields.summary: Show more useful linting details when bitbucket-pipelines.yml is not in correct format

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
Users are able to trigger builds for tags, when those are pushed on Bitbucket from a local repo.\\
However, adding a tag from Bitbucket UI does not trigger a build.

h3. Suggested Solution
Allow pipelines builds to get triggered when adding a tag from the UI.
fields.summary: As a user I want to trigger Pipeline builds when adding a tag from Bitbucket UI

fields.description:
If  the user plan limit is reached, when trying to add more users to the account, the user will be prompted with a ''It's time to upgrade' message -- on the message, there is a 'View' link, which links to the following URL: https://bitbucket.org/account/user/<username>/plan-users/, which is an invalid link

!1048689801-e818dafe05e9403fb095c31dafdd28fb.png|thumbnail!
fields.summary: Dead link when clicking the 'View' link from the 'It's time to upgrade' message

fields.description: Instead of running the pipeline when pushing into a branch, allow us to create a rule that only runs when a pull-request is created, matching by target branch name pattern.
fields.summary: Run pipeline for pull request only

fields.description:
Pipelines is not correctly executing the .bash_rc, causing several programs, that rely on bash aliases, to fail (eg. npm, grails, gem)

this often appears as "command not found"
fields.summary: Bitbucket pipelines - command not found

fields.description:
We need to be able to manage user access on the project level.\\
eg.

We have the Project A and the Project B.\\
There is 10 user with access to the team account Some_Team.\\
5 users belong to Project A and 5 users belong to Project B.

We want to be able to grant access to the Project A to the 5 users, and that the other 5 users, that have access to Project B, don't have access to the Project A repositories, vice versa.

Actually, it's only possible to grant and revoke the access to the repositories of a project, not the project itself.
fields.summary: Is there a way to handle user/group management on Project level ?

fields.description:
h3. Problem Definition
CodeDeploy add-on is sometimes used on certain repositories of a team/account, while other repositories of the same team/account use other deployment options.\\
Admins would like to have the option to disable the add-on for repos where it is not used, to prevent their team members from using it.

h3. Suggested Solution
Allow CodeDeploy add-on to be enabled/disabled per repository of the account/team where it is installed.
fields.summary: As an admin I would like to enable the CodeDeploy add-on on a per repo basis

fields.description:
Running the API using /2.0/repositories/{username}/{repo_slug}/pipelines/ shows the results from oldest to newest.

To provide an option to show results from newest to oldest.
fields.summary: To get pipelines result to show newest to oldest as an option through Rest API.

fields.description:
When creating a repo name begins with only (dot) symbols, the repo is created however inaccessible.

For example:

* .#
* .#,
* .***
* .!@#

Please contact Bitbucket Cloud support for further assistance.
fields.summary: Unable to access created repo name using (dot) symbols only ' .### '

fields.description: A repository with the name "something--cool" gets shortened to "something-cool" which is inconsistent with the behaviour supported locally and by Github.
fields.summary: Double hyphens in repository URL get collapsed to a single hyphen
API app passwords and curl documentation

fields.description:
When cloning a "big" (~3600 commits, 347.7 MB as indicated here) Mercurial repo I get various connection-related errors, see attached files.

My internet connection is otherwise steady and fast (120/10Mb/s) and I have no issues with anything else (including interacting with already cloned BB repos).

A few days ago I experienced similar errors on other "big" repos as well (bigger in file size at ~500MB but only 10s of commits max), from under another (even faster) internet connection. This was my first time seeing this issue. At first I thought the issue was that I was cloning to a slow storage (an SD card) but re-trying it with fast storage (various SSDs) the same issues arose multiple times.

The affected repos can be successfully cloned, but in my limited tests clone fails somehow in half, if not majority of the times.
fields.summary: Various connection errors when cloning big Mercurial repo

fields.description: Git allows the author and committer fields of a commit to be set separately. But the UI doesn't respect that difference and just shows one of the fields. The choice of fields is inconsistent: sometimes it uses the author field and calls it the committer and vice-versa.
fields.summary: Bitbucket UI does not distinguish between the author and committer fields for git commits

fields.description:
Hi,\\
Is there any plan for redesigning(or modernizing) Bitbucket repository\\
design?\\
It really looks old in my opinion.\\
Sincerely.
fields.summary: Redisign Bitbucket

fields.description:
My build uses a lot of memory when building in parallel.  Occasionally, due to the non-deterministic nature of parallel builds, it hits the memory limit, and the linux oom-killer kills my gcc process.  I've written my script to handle this (it retries with -j1), and the build completes fine.

The problem: pipelines reports this as a build failure, despite my script working.
fields.summary: Don't fail the build when pipelines memory limit is exceded

fields.description:
bq. I'd really like if, on the BitBucket's Pull Requests Dashboard, one could have, for every Pull Request on the list, the amount of change that it implies. I mean, an indicator condensing the number of lines (and files) added and/or removed.

That would go a long way helping us prioritize which requests to tackle first (and maybe offer some way of ordering them by that indicator, also).


--BBS-48679
fields.summary: Customer Request: Show amount of changes on Pull Request Dashboard
Support Git's patience diff algorithm

fields.description:
When creating a repository, a user is allowed to create a project using that same form. Using that functionality, the user only provides the project name (and not the key); the key is automatically generated from the name.

If the auto-generated key conflicts with another pre-existing key, then Bitbucket attempts to resolve the conflict by adding numbers at the end of the auto-generated key. Unfortunately, it uses a hyphen to separate the candidate key and the postfix number, which happens to be an illegal character. When a further attempt to modify *any* setting in that project is made, the attempt fails because an illegal key is in use.

Error message:

* Project keys must start with a letter and may only consist of ASCII letters, numbers and underscores (A-Z, a-z, 0-9, _)
fields.summary: Auto-created project key contains illegal characters

fields.description:
If a user create a write restriction for a pattern with wildcard, the user also can't create new branches that match the pattern. Example, if a user creates a restriction for "release/*", the user will never be able to create any branches under "release/"

A user should be able to do so for a few reasons - do review this use case by a user:

bq. Our project are currently using gitflow. There are 5 kind of branches: release/, hotfix/,\\
dev, master and feature/*. What we want is to prevent all changes without Pull Request > for master, hotfix, release, dev branches.

We have used Branch Permission to setup rules to require changes must be merged via\\
Pull Request and prevent pushing changes directly to master, hotfix, release, dev.\\
Because we don't allow changes to push directly, we also can't create new release and\\
hotfix branches. But as the gitflow, before any release or hotfix we have to create those\\
kind of branches.

There is a solution that is to create only one release and hotfix branched and every time > we change master, we have to create a Pull Request to merge that change to that\\
release and hotfix. But that is not standard of gitflow and it also causes our process\\
become more complicated.
fields.summary: If a user create a write restriction for a pattern with wildcard, the user also can't create new branches that match the pattern

fields.description: To help keep my build lean and troubleshoot issues, I'd love to see the time each script step took to execute.
fields.summary: Display approximate time per script step

fields.description:
The Wiki page for my software project contains the documentation for the latest release.

I'd like to provide users with a link to old revisions of a Wiki page so that they can read the documentation for older releases.

As far as I know, Github can do this quite easily (you can view any file at a given revision). I cannot find any documentation for doing the same in Bitbucket.
fields.summary: Linking to an old revision of a wiki page

fields.description: There is a 'translateZ(0px)' on the BitBucket dropdown navs which causes blurring of the inner elements in Chrome 56.0.2924.87 (64-bit) on Windows 10 (Removing the translateZ fixes the problem).
fields.summary: translateZ(0px) blurs navigation dropdowns

fields.description: Instead of displaying the number of days or months ago that a pipeline task was run, it would be more useful to know the date and and possibly the time when the job was started. I don't often care that a job was run 1 month ago, but I may be interested in knowing it ran on January 9.
fields.summary: Started column values on Pipelines project dashboard

fields.description:
It would be nice to be able to install a "pipeline agent" on an on premise server.\\
This could speed up some builds that requires very specific hardware configurations and/or save some build minutes from the bitbucket organization.
fields.summary: Install pipelines agent on an on premise server

fields.description:
As per this page -  https://developer.atlassian.com/bitbucket/api/2/reference/resource/repositories - it mentions that:

{code}
pagelen: integer 1..∞
Current number of objects on the existing page. The default value is 10 with 100 being the maximum allowed value. Individual APIs may enforce different values.
{code}

However:

# If I request https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories?pagelen=1000\\
it takes a long time but I get a working response with 1000 entries.
# If I request https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories?pagelen=5000\\
I immediately get back an error saying pagelen is too high.
# If I request https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories?pagelen=2000\\
I get a very long delay and then an HTTP internal server error 500.

pagelen should only allow 100 entries and not accepting any number beyond 100.
fields.summary: Customer report: https://api.bitbucket.org/2.0/repositories shouldn't allow pagelen above 100

fields.description:
Branch matching with glob patterns is not sufficient. We end up having to write out the same code multiple times to cover all of our branches. Moving this into a script is an option, but there is a lot of value in keeping these configurations simple and all in one file.

Here is an example pipelines file with this issue:

{code}
#!yaml

image: phpunit/phpunit:5.0.3
clone:
  depth: 1
pipelines:
  branches:
    master:
      - step:
          script:
            - do something
            - do something else
            - do something else
    develop:
      - step:
          script:
            - do something
            - do something else
            - do something else
    release/*:
      - step:
          script:
            - do something
            - do something else
            - do something else
{code}

And the same script with regular expressions:

{code}
#!yaml

image: phpunit/phpunit:5.0.3
clone:
  depth: 1
pipelines:
  branches:
    ~ ^develop|master|release/.*$:
      - step:
          script:
            - do something
            - do something else
            - do something else
{code}
fields.summary: Allow regular expressions for branch matching

fields.description:
We use feature/topic branches that we then merge to a main branch. It would be useful to trigger a Pipelines build when a Pull Request is created. The alternative at the moment is to trigger builds on a branch name pattern. This however has some disadvantages:

* Every commit on feature branches would trigger a build, we don't expect them to be all stable commits so this will just waste build minutes
* We'd need to enforce a branch naming convention (which might be a good thing in general but would be really annoying if your branch is not building because you misspelled something)

We've used PR triggers in other CI services and found them quite useful. I would suggest Pipelines having something like this:

{code}
#!yml

pipelines:
  branches:
    master
      - step:
  pull-request-into:
    master
       - step:
           ...
{code}

This way any PR into the specified branch will trigger a build when you create/update a PR
fields.summary: Trigger Pipelines on Pull Request
